subject: RE: [junit] TDD compared to tradition development coupled with automated unit test generation

messageBody:
The only auto-generation I've found useful is the simple test-class
template available in most IDEs, beyond that it would seem to both miss
the point of the analysis and learning inherent in creating a test and
leave you prone to suffering at the hands of an overly literal
test-generation algorithm. I would be very interested to hear of
anything better, but I do find it difficult to imagine anything that
would be capable of replacing the value of even a poor set of
hand-written tests.

If you just like the idea of tools as rewarding toys, then I like
Jester (http://jester.sourceforge.net/), although it isn't exactly
simple to integrate into a development environment.

I think Kevin Klinemeier caught the more approachable issue, which is
how to encourage a team to develop their own tests. In addition to his
advice I can only suggest that you:

1. Ask them to create tests as part of normal development tasks.
2. Give them time to create the tests (although you will eventually
find the tests save time, they will need more time up-front).
3. Support them in creating the tests and don't place great pressure on
them over it, especially if the underlying development is pressurised
already.
4. Evaluate tests together, perhaps have a group task where each person
creates a test for a class or method and then you compare and discuss
(this is where jester can be quite valuable in exposing test
blind-spots).
5. Link bug-fixing to test creation -- assuming that you have a
bug-database, this is an effective way of adding tests of value to
existing code.
6. If you feel they won't react badly to it, consider writing seed
tests yourself.


Although we're meant to be rational, technical people, this is one of
the many issues that is more problematic on an emotional level than it
is in any practical sense. Only you know your team and how they work and
it could be that none of the above would be useful for you. I can't
claim to have cracked the problem myself, but there's always hope.

Best of luck with it,


Damian Sinclair
